L/ws R. 1
6/.hifi
Separation of Ectoderm and Endoderm/Mesoderm
of Sea Urchin Embryos and Pluteus Larvae
The dissociation and isolation procedures described here are based on the presence
of a basal lamina that lines the blastocoel wall of the post-hatching embryo and on a
differential effect of glycine-EDTA on the germ layers of the developing embryo. The
protocol as outlined is adopted from several sources (references listed below), and it
should be noted that optimal times for glycine-EDTA treatment will vary with species of
urchin (McClay and Marchose, 1979).
The Strongylocentrotus purpuratus pluteus larvae that we utilize here are at
65 72 hr of development. The method works as well for earlier embryonic stages (Harkey
and Whitely, l980).
Wash plutei several times by gentle centrifugation and resuspension in ice-cold
MFSW.
lr
Wash the final pluteus pellet very briefly by resuspension in 4-5 vol ice-cold
glycine-EDTA, followed by centrifugation. Immediately aspirate off (pour off) the
supernatant (discard).
Resuspend the pellet in 4-5 vol glycine-EDTA. NOTE: For species that are
particularly susceptible to dissociation in glycine-EDTA, omit Step2 and use
40 vol glycine-EDTA in Step 3. 
lncubate on ice for 4 min.
Sediment the plutei and quickly aspirate off the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in vol ice-cold NOTE: The plutei are not
dissociated by the brief glycine-EDTA treatment which extracts hyalin. They
should be intact, the ectoderm cells remaining attached to the basal lamina lying
beneath the ectoderm layer, but should have a "loose" appearance that is due to the
absence of the hyalin layer.
Dissociate the plutei by pulling the suspension syringe (without a needle) 20 times or by pipetting up and down using a Pasteur
pipette. This removes the ectoderm cells and leaves the basal lamina as an intact
"bag" covering the skeleton and endoderm. NOTE: After the plutei are removed
from glycine and resuspended in dissociation should be begun within several
minutes, as they become increasingly difficult to dissociate with longer delays due
to regeneration of the hyalin layer.
Sediment the bags out of the plutei suspension. They pellet
with gentle centrifugation, for example, 20 sec in a clinical tabletop centrifuge, or
at 250><g for 1+ min (Harkey and Whitely, l980). Save the supernatant which
contains the ectoderm cells. Wash the bag pellet 2-3 times with FSW. Monitor the
bag fraction until it is free of ectoderm cells.
Filter the ectoderm supernatant through Nitex-28 um. The filtrate contains
ectoderm cells, and the retentate contains contaminating bags. Collect the
ectoderm cells by centrifuging the filtrate at 650><g for 10 min, and resuspend the
cells in MFSW.
